comments.body:
```suggestion
class SerializedDag(Base):
```

And then call this `SerialzedDagModel` at import time if we need to distinguish this.

The problem is it will collide a lot in the same file & so become confusing:

https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/e2570ca0002394af9f59703a2b29ad21642c546b/airflow/models/serialized_dag.py#L73

https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/e2570ca0002394af9f59703a2b29ad21642c546b/airflow/models/serialized_dag.py#L34-L37`

I can obviously add `as` on those imports to change but not sure if it is worth it, WDYT?
Why would `self.data` have two formats here?

This probably isn't needed, but might be for cases where SQLAlchemy doesn't handle the JSON deserialize for us.

We should remove this if we can though, yes.
Yes, older versions of Mysql don't support json type and sqlalchemy returns string. Best example is our CI images with MySQL
Do you have information about which MySQL version does not support this?  Maybe it is worth abandoning the support for some versions to be able to go further in the future e.g. with JSON index etc.

>MySQL as of version 5.7 (MariaDB as of the 10.2 series does not)

https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/core/type_basics.html#sqlalchemy.types.JSON
Makes more sense to move the `log.debug("Writing DAG: %s to the DB", dag)` line here, because the interval check is done before writing the DAG.
ðŸ‘

comments.body: I believe it will be better to use  hash of the file itself rather than Json representation. Not only it will be faster (you d note have to parse the file and create a SerializedDAG, but also it will be more accurate (there are some changes like comments that might cause the Serialized DAG to be the same (comments, jinja templates etc.). Of course it will be still ok (we care about Serialized representation in this case) but I think it would be more accurate to refresh Serialized DAG and hash every time when the file changes. Also it wil be much easier to reason about that hash and verify if it is correct or whether the file changed since - we just need to check the hash of the file on disk.

The main reason for using Hash of a Serialized DAG is related to the question I asked Airbnb folks:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8811558/89730618-39257000-da38-11ea-828f-076cff27102e.png)

>Question for cong zhu: Do you store Hash of the DAG File? What happens when the modules imported by the DAG File changes bu not the DAG files itself, in that case DAG file hash remains the same but DAG might not be the same
>Cong Zhu: Yes, we store the hash of the serialized DAG

i.e. I have seen cases where people import Schedule Interval, operators and other properties from a different file. If they change the imported file, the Hash of the DAG file remains the same but Serialized DAG changes
Ah Right! Makes sense indeed. Great to get some input from AirBnB folks on that one :)

comments.body:
I am still not sure if we explicitly require `foreign` keyword over here.

Can you explain why it is needed?

based on the 2nd section in https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/join_conditions.html#creating-custom-foreign-conditions

>An alternative syntax to the above is to use the foreign() and remote() annotations, inline within the relationship.primaryjoin expression. This syntax represents the annotations that relationship() normally applies by itself to the join condition given the relationship.foreign_keys and relationship.remote_side arguments. These functions may be more succinct when an explicit join condition is present, and additionally serve to mark exactly the column that is â€œforeignâ€ or â€œremoteâ€ independent of whether that column is stated multiple times or within complex SQL expressions:
You are right. I tested and we don't need that. I am new to Airflow and SQLAlchemy tbh :).

Looks like the CI failed with following error:

```
sqlalchemy.exc.InvalidRequestError: One or more mappers failed to initialize - can't proceed with initialization of other mappers. Triggering mapper: 'mapped class SerializedDagModel->serialized_dag'. Original exception was: Could not locate any relevant foreign key columns for primary join condition 'serialized_dag.dag_id = dag_run.dag_id' on relationship SerializedDagModel.dag_runs.  Ensure that referencing columns are associated with a ForeignKey or ForeignKeyConstraint, or are annotated in the join condition with the foreign() annotation.
```

So indeed it looks like we do need `foreign`

or maybe it just requires the following:

```
primaryjoin="SerializedDagModel.dag_id == foreign(DagRun.dag_id)",
```

based on example in https://stackoverflow.com/a/57454638/5691525

diffHunk:

        DagRun,
        primaryjoin=dag_id == foreign(DagRun.dag_id),
        backref=backref('serialized_dag', uselist=False, innerjoin=True),
    )
